lll. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12214 Compliance with the child protection
Section law.
Description (1) An agency shall comply with the child protection law, 1975 PA
238, MCL 722.621 to 722.638.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation There are concerns that a foster parent maintains a license given
they adopted a relative child who was sexually abused and
murdered by the foster parent's boyfriend.
Investigation It should be noted the allegation states, “child who was sexually
abused and murdered by the foster parent's boyfriend.” This is
inaccurate information; the alleged Perpetrator is the boyfriend of
Foster Parent’s Daughter and not Foster Parent.
Complainant was interviewed 1/17/2025 via telephone. She
reported she received all her information about the case from
watching social media. She did not have any first-hand
information. No additional information was added.
Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed on 1/23/25, via
video conference and face-to-face on 2/18/25. She reported
Catholic Charities Southeast Michigan (CCSEM) did not hold the
foster care portion of Adoptive Child A’s case. This was managed
by Oakland County DHHS. She reported on 9/21/17, an Order of
Adoption for Adoptive Child A was signed by Wayne County
Court. CA reported Foster Parent of Adoptive Child A became a
general licensed foster parent with CCSEM on 4/27/18. At this
time, Foster Parent was already the Adoptive Mother of Adoptive
Child A, who is her granddaughter. CCSEM had no assigned
responsibility for Adoptive Child A per Licensing Rules for Child
Placing Agencies.
Foster Parent is the adoptive mother to Adoptive Child A and will
be referred to as Foster Parent from here on.
CA reported the last placement from CCSEM into Foster Parent’s
home was Foster Child A (FCA). She reported FCA was placed
from 10/26/23 – 12/19/23, in the home with the Foster Parent prior
to Adoptive Child A going missing. Foster Parent reported the
information to Licensing Worker that her granddaughter went
missing on 2/14/24. She reported to the Licensing Worker that
2

Adoptive Child A had run away. Licensing Worker reported this
information to the CA. CA said upon receiving the information that
Adoptive Child A was missing, the agency discussed this news
with their administrative staff and reviewed the foster home rules
to make sure every foster home rule was followed regarding their
role under the rules. She said it was determined based on a
review of MiSACWIS history, DHHS policy and Child Placing
Agency rules that there was no established policy or rule for the
agency to follow or act on. Adoptive Child A was not an active
foster child, thus foster care protocols did not apply.
CA reported there is currently an active investigation on the Foster
Parent with CCSEM, in conjunction with MDHHS.
CA reported CCSEM has had no knowledge or awareness of
Perpetrator, including his connection to the family or concerns
towards Adoptive Child A’s safety or her alleged relationship with
him. No one including Foster Parent has ever mentioned anything
to the agency about Perpetrator. Foster Parent’s daughter, who is
the girlfriend of Perpetrator, has not been listed as a member of
the household or a household member associated with Foster
Parent and her license. CA stated MiSACWIS history shows no
prior MDHHS intakes or reports regarding Foster Parent home.
Licensing Supervisor (LS) was interviewed on 1/23/25, via
video conference. LS reported after learning of Adoptive Child
A’s disappearance on 2/14/2024, the assigned Licensing Worker
maintained contact with Foster Parent monthly for support and in
preparation for the renewal. LS spoke with Foster Parent about
Adoptive Child A’s disappearance. Foster Parent reported she
went to the school to see if the school knew anything about
Adoptive Child A’s disappearance or her where abouts and the
school called the Detroit Police Department (DPD). LS said Foster
Parent waited at the school to speak with DPD and shared that
Adoptive Child A did not come home on 1/9/24 nor called Foster
Parent, and she has never done this in the past.
The agency did not receive any updates from the law enforcement
investigation, and it is unknown when their investigation began
pertaining to the criminal involvement. MDHHS began their
investigation approximately on 1/12/2025 pertaining to the
allegations of abuse or neglect by Foster Parent.
LS reported upon the case becoming public knowledge that
Adoptive Child A was presumed deceased the agency again
reviewed Child Placing Agency Rules to determine their agency’s
3

compliance. LS reported when the information became public
knowledge on social media, a contact was received by MDHHS
asking if Foster Parent was still licensed with CCSEM and if
Foster Parent had any children placed in her home. LS reported
that the MDHHS representative was informed that Foster Parent
was still licensed with the agency and no children were placed in
her home. LS reported that Foster Parent never mentioned there
were any allegations of abuse and neglect in her home.
Program Manager (PM) was interviewed on 1/23/25, via video
conference and face-to-face 2/18/25. She reported on 1/17/25,
CCSEM became aware that a MDHHS investigation was initiated
on Foster Parent. She reported when the agency learned that an
investigation was initiated, CCSEM initiated a special evaluation.
PM reported the agency was not notified of the MDHHS intakes
on 1/11/25 and 1/12/25 by MDHHS. She reported she was looking
in MiSACWIS and saw that an investigation was initiated on
Foster Parent by MDHHS. PM reported LS reached out to the
assigned Lead MDHHS Worker upon learning of an investigation
of Foster Parent that was initiated in MiSACWIS. The Lead
MDHHS Worker shared with PM that she was a new worker and
was recently assigned to conduct the investigation on Foster
Parent regarding the disappearance of Adoptive Child A and any
involvement Foster Parent may have had in this disappearance.
The Lead MDHHS Worker explained to PM she did not know she
was to contact the private agency and inform them an active
investigation was opened on Foster Parent.
PM reported the Lead MDHHS Worker had not yet made a
determination of abuse or neglect regarding Foster Parent based
on information learned at that time.
Licensing Worker (LW) was interviewed on 3/24/25, via
telephone. LW has been working with Foster Parent since Foster
Parent’s home was licensed with CCSEM on 4/27/18. She
reported when she went to the home of Foster Parent on 9/24/24,
she discussed with Foster Parent about the completion of a
missing person report for Adoptive Child A. Foster Parent said she
had completed the report on 1/10/24 because she thought she
had to wait 24 hours to report a missing person. LW reported
Foster Parent reported Adoptive Child A had never been late
returning home from school, nor had she indicated that Adoptive
Child A had ran away from home in the past. LW reported Foster
Parent then told her she believes that Adoptive Child A had ran
away and has not contacted her to discuss her where abouts. LW
reported she advised Foster Parent to maintain open
4

communication with the local police department regarding
Adoptive Child A’s disappearance and to keep the agency abreast
to any information or changes regarding Adoptive Child A.
LW reported during the last year's home assessment, the home
remained clean and maintained, and she did not observe any
safety issues in the home. LW reported at no time did Foster
Parent discuss with her that she knew the Perpetrator and that
any allegations of abuse/neglect ever occurred in her home. LW
reported the only thing Foster Parent said to her was Adoptive
Child A was missing, she believed she had run away and she was
very worried about Adoptive Child A’s disappearance. Foster
Parent A reported to LW that Adoptive Child A disappeared on
1/9/24. However, Foster Parent did not share this information with
CCSEM until LW went to the home to complete a home visit for
the upcoming renewal on 2/14/24.
Foster Parent was interviewed on 3/24/25 via telephone. She
reported there has never been abuse/neglect in her home and her
adoptive children were well taken care of. She reported she had
no knowledge of Perpetrator’s involvement of any criminal sexual
conduct (CSC). She reported she never gave Adoptive Child A
permission to go anywhere with Perpetrator. She said this
decision was made by Foster Parent’s Daughter. Foster Parent
reported Perpetrator never came into her home and she did not
have a relationship with him. Foster Parent reported when LW
came to her home on 2/14/25 and she shared with LW that
Adoptive Child A went missing on 1/9/24. Foster Parent said she
never shared anything with CCSEM regarding Perpetrator
because she did not know him and did not have any type of
relationship with him.
Foster Parent Daughter was interviewed on 3/24/25, via
telephone. She reported she is the daughter of Foster Parent.
Foster Parent Daughter reported she had a long-standing
relationship with Perpetrator and produced five children. She
reported the only information she had regarding Perpetrator’s
criminal history that came from Perpetrator was that he spent time
in jail for carrying a concealed weapon and had a gun charge.
She reported prior to that, when she got pregnant with her first
child at nineteen years old, her aunt took her to get a pregnancy
test and asked her if she knew Perpetrator. She reported she told
her aunt that Perpetrator told her he had a gun charge. She said
her aunt told her when the two of them returned home, she was
going to look Perpetrator up on the website. Foster Parent
Daughter said her aunt told her that Perpetrator had an Criminal
5

Sexual Conduct (CSC) charge. She said she mentioned this
information to Perpetrator, and he told her he was dating a person
who lied about her age, and nothing occurred with the CSC
incident. Foster Parent Daughter reported she never told anyone
about the discussion she had with Perpetrator about his CSC
charge. She said Perpetrator denied he had a charge with CSC,
and she believed him. She said the two of them never mentioned
an allegation of CSC again. She reported she has had an eleven-
year relationship with the Perpetrator off and on and to her
knowledge, he had not had any contact with young girls. She said
he had a lot of female relationships during their courtship. She
reported she was not married to him, and he dated other women
and there was nothing she could do about it.
Foster Parent Daughter reported she never lived with Foster
Parent during the time she was dating Perpetrator, but she spoke
with Foster Parent often and occasionally visited Foster Parent in
her home. She reported Perpetrator had a car shop and he asked
if any of the children wanted to make some money by cleaning up
the shop. She said she told him their eleven-year-old daughter
they had together could clean the shop with her cousin, Adoptive
Child A. She said she called Foster Parent and asked for
permission for Adoptive Child A to help clean up the shop with her
cousin and she was granted permission from Foster Parent due to
Foster Parent Daughter knowing Perpetrator and Perpetrator was
the father of Foster Parent Daughter’s eleven-year-old daughter.
Foster Parent Daughter reported at no time did Perpetrator go into
Foster Parent’s home. She said Perpetrator would pick up their
eleven-year-old daughter and go to the home of Foster Parent and
pick up Adoptive Child A. She said Adoptive Child A would go to
Perpetrator’s truck that was parked in front of Foster Parent’s
driveway, get in the vehicle and the three of them (her daughter,
Adoptive Child A, and Perpetrator) would go and clean up the
shop and the girls would be dropped back off at their respective
homes. She reported she learned of Perpetrator’s CSC charges
more thoroughly through social media when everyone else
learned of his charges. Foster Parent Daughter reported she
never reported abuse/neglect to CCSEM because she was not
aware of nor observed any type of abuse/neglect in Foster
Parent’s home.
It is noted the aunt was not interviewed for this investigation as
she does not want to be involved with this case. No information,
including a telephone number was provided for her.
6

It is noted that MDHHS’s investigation is active. The agency was
not permitted to be involved with the MDHHS interviews for the
case. However, LS reported she checks on the status of the case
weekly. Once the case is marked closed in MiSACWIS, LS will
send a request for a copy of the report to the redaction unit to
obtain a copy of the MDHHS investigation report.
Document reviewed:
• Adoptive Child A’s adoption record. Adoptive Child A was
adopted by Foster Parent on 9/21/17, when she was seven
years old.
• Foster Child A was placed in Foster Parent’s home from
10/26/23 – 12/19/23.
• Foster Parents’s renewal evaluation dated 10/26/23 –
10/25/24. The report did not focus on what occurred
regarding Adoptive Child A’s disappearance. The report
focused on how losses are dealt with. There is a statement
in the report that the family is grieving the loss of Adoptive
Child A who went missing on January 9, 2024. The report
stated it was recently reported by the local police
department that an arrest was made in kidnapping, sexual
assault and murder of Adoptive Child A and at this time the
case is an open and active investigation. The
recommendation was that Foster Parent continue on a
regular license for 2 children, male or female, ages 0-12 for
the following service types: General care, unrelated
caregiver, short term substitute care, developmentally
delayed, and medication administration.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as interviews with Foster
Parent, Foster Parent Daughter, and agency staff concluded the
agency did not suspect abuse when they initially received
information from Foster Parent on 2/14/24 regarding Adoptive
Child A’s disappearance. Agency Staff reported Adoptive Child A
was not a foster Child, rather the Foster Parent’s adoptive
daughter, and the agency had no jurisdiction over Adoptive Child
A.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
7

Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
Section (1) Upon receipt of any information that relates to possible
Description noncompliance with any foster home rule, the agency must do all
the following:
(b) Initiate a special evaluation of the foster home as soon as is
indicated, based on the information received, but not later than 7
calendar days after receipt of the information.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation There are concerns the agency learned of possible licensing
violations on Foster Parent’s home regarding Adoptive Child A’s
disappearance and did not initiate a special evaluation.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed on 1/17/25 via telephone. She
reported no additional information.
LS was interviewed on 1/23/25, via video conference and
face-to-face on 2/18/25. She reported there were several special
evaluations of Foster Parent. LS reported there was one special
evaluation where there were violations established, and Foster
Parent was given a corrective action plan whereby this was
monitored weekly until it’s completion. LS reported there were
several investigations initiated, assigned and investigated by the
agency licensing department. LS reported as soon as the
information was reported to the agency, the agency licensing
department initiated special evaluations and followed licensing
protocol. LS reported the same information as CA regarding
learning of possible violations of Foster Parent when Adoptive
Child A disappeared. She said when the agency received the
information about Adoptive Child A’s disappearance on 2/14/25
from LW and Foster Parent, and when the agency learned from
the PM that Foster Parent had an active investigation with
MDHHS due to reviewing information in MiSACWIS, CCSEM
initiated an investigation on Foster Parent as well. LS reported
MDHHS did not inform the agency that they had initiated an
investigation on their Foster Parent on 1/11/25 and 1/12/25. She
said upon learning of the intakes on Foster Parent on the above-
mentioned dates, PM reached out to the Lead MDHHS Worker
and was informed Lead MDHHS Worker was aware that Foster
Parent was a licensed foster parent but did not know what to do or
how to inform CCSEM that they were investigating Foster Parent.
She reported she was a new MDHHS Worker assigned to the
case. LW reported the agency discussed the disappearance of
Adoptive Child A with their administrative staff and reviewed the
foster home rules to make sure every foster home rule was
8

followed regarding the agency role under the foster home rules.
She said it was determined based on a review of MiSACWIS
history, MDHHS policy and DCWL rules that there was no
established policy or rule for the agency to follow or act on.
Adoptive Child A was not an active foster child, thus foster home
rules did not apply related to this youth. LW reported to their
knowledge regarding foster home rules, there was no possible
violations associated with Adoptive Child A’s disappearance.
Licensing Worker (LW) was interviewed on 3/24/25, via
telephone. LW has been working with Foster Parent since Foster
Parent was originally licensed through CCSEM on 4/27/2018.
Foster Parent reported to LW that Adoptive Child A disappeared
on 1/9/24. However, Foster Parent did not share this information
with CCSEM until LW went to the home to complete a home visit
on 2/14/24 in preparation for the renewal. LW met with Foster
Parent each month and never learned or observed any potential
licensing violations.
Foster Parent was interviewed via telephone 3/24/25. She
reported anytime an allegation was reported on her home, the
agency called her and to let her know she had an active
investigation open on her home and that she was welcome to
invite a support person. She reported the agency would come
inspect her home, interview all of the adopted children in the home
individually and in a private area. She stressed she does not hurt
children, and she would never beat or abuse the children in her
home. Foster Parent did not report any possible licensing
violations to the agency regarding Adoptive Child A’s
disappearance.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Special Investigation Report SI# 2022C0631004 dated
6/28/22. The allegation “alleges that the children placed in
Foster Parent’s home, are unsafe. It was reported that
Foster Parent has abused her biological children in the past
and they have suffered from physical, sexual, and
emotional abuse. It was also reported that Foster Parent
"Whoops" her adoptive children and tells them not to tell
their adoption worker. It was also alleged that the unknown
aunt, "Whoops" the children.” There were no rule
violations, and the license recommendation was
Unchanged (No Violations Established).
• Special Investigation Report SI# 2022C0631155 dated
08/11/2022. The allegation was, “Foster Parent
transported a foster child who was placed in her home from
9

4/15/21-12/1/22 to Children's Hospital, on 8/5/2022, at 3:57
p.m. and discharged on 8/6/2022, at 3:19 p.m. Foster
Parent did not contact her foster care case manager or the
emergency phone to provide information that foster child
was being admitted to the hospital. Hospital documentation
reports that foster child was discharged with Acute
Constipation. Foster Parent was in violation with Foster
Home rule 400.9403 Foster parent duties. The
recommendation was upon receipt of an acceptable CAP,
the license remain unchanged. The CAP was successfully
completed by Foster Parent.
• Prior to the two investigations mentioned above, the
agency assigned and investigated the following allegations
that were called in by an anonymous caller:
2018SEC0625603 – initiated 6/15/2018 – no violation.
2019SEC0626485 – initiated 12/14/2018 – no violation.
2019SEC0626624 – initiated 1/15/2019 – no violation.
2019SEC0626735 – initiated 2/4/2019 – no violation.
2022SEC0627497 – initiated 6/14/2019 – no violation.
2022SEC0630736 - initiated 4/13/2022 – no violation.
Analysis Based on interviews, documentation and the number of special
investigations that were initiated and investigated by the agency
on the Foster Parent, the agency is found in compliance as there
is evidence that the agency responded to the allegations and the
information provided to them by an anonymous caller. The agency
initiated all of the special investigations which was timely and per
special investigation rule. The situation with Adoptive Child A
being missing did not require an investigation.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
10

III. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
